Body: Italian has diphthongs when you put together two vowels, like in the word "uomo". As far as I understand a diphthong is not necessarily a glide, because a glide has to be less sonorous than a vowel. So I'm asking: are there real glides in Italian, and can you provide examples?
Title: Are there glides in Italian?

OwnerUser.AboutMe: I am a PhD student (Physics, working on quantitative Linguistics).
